        In situ hydrothermal synthesis of tetrazole coordination polymers with interesting physical properties
        Zhao, Hong; Qu, Zhi-Rong; Ye, Heng-Yun; Xiong, Ren-Gen
        Chemical Society Reviews (2008), 37 (1), 84-100CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Tetrazole compds. have been studied for more than one hundred years and applied in various areas. Several yeas ago Sharpless and his co-workers reported an environmentally friendly process for the prepn. of 5-substituted 1H-tetrazoles in water with zinc salt as catalysts. To reveal the exact role of the zinc salt in this reaction, a series of hydrothermal reactions aimed at trapping and characterizing the solid intermediates were investigated. This study allowed us to obtain a myriad of interesting metal-org. coordination polymers that not only partially showed the role of the metal species in the synthesis of tetrazole compds. but also provided a class of complexes displaying interesting chem. and phys. properties such as second harmonic generation (SHG), fluorescence, ferroelec. and dielec. behaviors. In this tutorial review, we will mainly focus on tetrazole coordination compds. synthesized by in situ hydrothermal methods. First, we will discuss the synthesis and crystal structures of these compds. Their various properties will be mentioned and we will show the applications of tetrazole coordination compds. in org. synthesis. Finally, we will outline some expectations in this area of chem. The direct coordination chem. of tetrazoles to metal ions and in situ synthesis of tetrazole through cycloaddn. between organotin azide and org. cyano group will be not discussed in this review.

        Novel, acentric metal-organic coordination polymers from hydrothermal reactions involving in situ ligand synthesis
        Xiong, Ren-Gen; Xue, Xiang; Zhao, Hong; You, Xiao-Zeng; Abrahams, Brendan F.; Xue, Ziling
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (20), 3800-3803CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A structural study of the products or intermediates in the hydrothermal reaction of ZnCl2 (or CdCl2) with 3-cyanopyridine (or 4-cyanopyridine) and NaN3 in H2O was conducted. The strong powder SHG response of 3 may be attributed to a good donor-acceptor system in which the pyridyl ring acts as acceptor and the tetrazole ring as donor. A wide variety of coordination polymers can be produced by hydrothermal generation of bridging ligands in the presence of appropriate metal ions. In particular, the formation of ligands such as 3-ptz and 4-ptz that tend to place metal atoms in irregular arrangements but still gave infinite networks offers good prospects for generating acentric cryst. materials that may possess desirable phys. properties such as SHG.

        Structure validation in chemical crystallography
        Spek, Anthony L.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography (2009), 65 (2), 148-155CODEN: ABCRE6; ISSN:0907-4449. (International Union of Crystallography)
        A review. Automated structure validation was introduced in chem. crystallog. about 12 years ago as a tool to assist practitioners with the exponential growth in crystal structure analyses. Validation has since evolved into an easy-to-use checkCIF/PLATON web-based IUCr service. The result of a crystal structure detn. has to be supplied as a CIF-formatted computer-readable file. The checking software tests the data in the CIF for completeness, quality, and consistency. In addn., the reported structure is checked for incomplete anal., errors in the anal., and relevant issues to be verified. A validation report is generated in the form of a list of ALERTS on the issues to be cor., checked, or commented on. Structure validation has largely eliminated obvious problems with structure reports published in IUCr journals, such as refinement in a space group of too low symmetry. This paper reports on the current status of structure validation and possible future extensions.

        Multicomponent Assembly of Fluorescent-Tag Functionalized Ligands in Metal-Organic Frameworks for Sensing Explosives
        Gole, Bappaditya; Bar, Arun Kumar; Mukherjee, Partha Sarathi
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2014), 20 (41), 13321-13336CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Detection of trace amts. of explosive materials is significantly important for security concerns and pollution control. Four multicomponent metal-org. frameworks (MOFs-12, 13, 23, and 123) were synthesized by employing ligands embedded with fluorescent tags. The multicomponent assembly of the ligands was utilized to acquire a diverse electronic behavior of the MOFs and the fluorescent tags were strategically chosen to enhance the electron d. in the MOFs. Moreover, the recyclability and sensitivity studies indicated that these MOFs can be reused several times with ppb levels of sensitivity towards PC and 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT).

The key role of the chosen arom. tags is to enhance the π-electron d. of the luminescent MOFs. Single-crystal X-ray structures have revealed that these MOFs form three-dimensional porous networks with the arom. tags projecting inwardly into the pores. These highly luminescent electron-rich MOFs have been successfully utilized for the detection of explosive nitroarom. compds. (NACs) on the basis of fluorescence quenching. Although all of the prepd. MOFs can serve as sensors for NACs, MOF-1 and MOF-2 exhibit superior sensitivity towards 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT) and 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT) compared to 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT) and 1,3,5-trinitrobenzene (TNB). MOF-3, on the other hand, shows an order of sensitivity in accordance with the electron deficiencies of the substrates. To understand such anomalous behavior, we have thoroughly analyzed both the steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence quenching assocd. with these interactions. Detn. of static Stern-Volmer consts. (KS) as well as collisional consts. (KC) has revealed that MOF-1 and MOF-2 have higher KS values with 4-NT than with TNT, whereas for MOF-3 the reverse order is obsd. This apparently anomalous phenomenon was well corroborated by theor. calcns. Moreover, recyclability and sensitivity studies have revealed that these MOFs can be reused several times and that their sensitivities towards TNT soln. are at the ppb level.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      68. 68
        Pramanik, S.; Zheng, C.; Zhang, X.; Emge, T. J.; Li, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 4153 DOI: 10.1021/ja106851d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        68
        New Microporous Metal-Organic Framework Demonstrating Unique Selectivity for Detection of High Explosives and Aromatic Compounds
        Pramanik, Sanhita; Zheng, Chong; Zhang, Xiao; Emge, Thomas J.; Li, Jing
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (12), 4153-4155CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The authors report a highly luminescent metal-org. framework(MMOF), [Zn2(oba)2(bpy)]·DMA (I) H2oba is 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid); bpy is 4,4-bipyridine; DMA is N,N-dimethylacetamide, and its unique photoluminescence (PL) properties. the authors' studies on its guest-free form revealed unique fluorescence quenching and enhancement behavior upon exposure to the vapor of arom. compds. of group A with electron-withdrawing groups and group B with electron-donating groups, resp. The results demonstrate the exceptional ability of the guest-free form of I to selectively detect explosives of different types (e.g., arom. DNT vs. nonarom. or aliph. dimethyldinitrobutane). The origin of such an effect can be understood and explained from MO and band structure calcns. as well as a comparison of their electrochem. properties. Clearly, the nature of the analyte mols. and the electronic structure and porosity of the MMOF all play key roles in the emission properties.

        Exploitation of Guest Accessible Aliphatic Amine Functionality of a Metal-Organic Framework for Selective Detection of 2,4,6-Trinitrophenol (TNP) in Water
        Mukherjee, Soumya; Desai, Aamod V.; Manna, Biplab; Inamdar, Arif I.; Ghosh, Sujit K.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2015), 15 (9), 4627-4634CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Highly selective and sensitive aq. phase-detection of the well-known nitro explosive environmental pollutant 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) by a water-stable, porous luminescent metal-org. framework is reported. The presence of a guest accessible aliph. amine functionality in the MOF channels was strategically harnessed for serving the purpose of exclusive TNP-sensing in water even in concurrent presence of other nitro arom. and nitro aliph. analytes.

      71. 71
        Vishnoi, P.; Walawalkar, M. G.; Sen, S.; Datta, A.; Patwari, G. N.; Murugavel, R. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16, 10651 DOI: 10.1039/c4cp00930d
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        71
        Selective fluorescence sensing of polynitroaromatic explosives using triaminophenylbenzene scaffolds
        Vishnoi, Pratap; Walawalkar, Mrinalini G.; Sen, Saumik; Datta, Anindya; Patwari, G. Naresh; Murugavel, Ramaswamy
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (22), 10651-10658CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A supramol. fluorophore, 1,3,5-tris(4'-aminophenyl)benzene (TAPB), selectively senses polynitroarom. compds. (PNAC), viz. 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), picric acid (PA), m-dinitrobenzene (m-DNB), and p-dinitrobenzene (p-DNB) through donor-acceptor complexation. Steady-state and time resolved fluorescence measurements indicate predominantly static quenching of the TAPB fluorophore with TNT, DNT, m-DNB, and p-DNB. In the case of PA, a new emissive band with a marginally longer lifetime emerges due to complex formation with TAPB. The selectivity of sensing action is rationalized through computation of HOMO and LUMO energies for both the fluorophore and the analytes using the M06-2X/6-311+G(d,p) level of theory. Practical utility of the fluorophore has also been demonstrated with TNT and DNT vapor.
